caption_original: Last month we participated in “Exercise Salish Sea,” which was the largest largest major incident exercise in Canadian Coast Guard history! The two-day major maritime incident training exercise took place east of Salt Spring Island, British Columbia. Day one focused on search and rescue and involved the evacuation of 100 survivors from a BC Ferry. Canadian Armed Forces Transport and Infrastructure in Canada BC Ferries Royal Canadian Marine Search and Rescue U.S. Coast Guard

caption_original:
Fun Fact Friday:
We are proud to have 114 ships, 23 helos, & 4,500 members working 24/7 to protect & secure the largest coastline in the world.

We are the leading maritime authority in the country, operating 24/7 in some of the most challenging conditions on the earth to provide services that are critical to safety, security and economic growth.

caption_original:
The Canadian Transportation Agency is committed to an open and transparent dialogue with Canadians and welcomes a variety of perspectives and opinions. We believe that only by being open to challenge, debate and a free and honest exchange of ideas can we ensure that we are serving Canadians to the best of our ability. 

However, feedback should be at all times respectful and relevant. It should not include personal attacks or innuendo directed at individual public servants who perform their jobs with dedication and professionalism. 

For more information, visit https://www.otc-cta.gc.ca/eng/use-social-media.
caption_cleaned: The Canadian Transportation Agency is committed to an open and transparent dialogue with Canadians and welcomes a variety of perspectives and opinions. We believe that only by being open to challenge, debate and a free and honest exchange of ideas can we ensure that we are serving Canadians to the best of our ability. However, feedback should be at all times respectful and relevant. It should not include personal attacks or innuendo directed at individual public servants who perform their jobs with dedication and professionalism. For more information, visit .

caption_original: Would you believe these pictures were taken back to back? One of our scientists working at the Eureka Weather Station in Eureka, Nunavut, went for a morning walk. Due to the moon being in its waning phase, the sun and the moon were clearly visible at the same time. The waning moon rises during the night, is visible in the morning, and sets during the day. After capturing this cool shot of a muskox and the moon, she turned around and saw a beautiful sunrise. : Renee Cossitt....

caption_original: The clouds ️ pictured are called mammatus. Mammatus are formed from outpouching of water vapour high in the atmosphere. They are often (but not always) seen in the anvil of strong thunderstorms, as was the case on this summer day!.... : Kyle Fougere

caption_original: Summer throwback! In these photos, Hannah and Paul, graduate students from Dr. Koper’s lab at the University of Manitoba, are collaborating with Barry, an employee of the Canadian Wildlife Service to monitor Baird’s Sparrow survival on breeding grounds outside of Brooks in southeastern Alberta. This project is part of a tri-national collaboration between Canada, the USA, and Mexico, with the goal of determining where and when the bird is most limited: on the breeding grounds in Canada and the USA, or the wintering grounds in Mexico. To monitor survival, we are deploying tiny Very High Frequency (VHF) transmitters in Alberta, while our partners at the Bird Conservancy of the Rockies deploy transmitters in Montana, North Dakota and Mexico. ...

caption_original:
Canadians had plenty of weather to talk about this year! Flooding caused significant damage in parts of Quebec and Ontario, while winter storms walloped Atlantic Canada. British Columbians faced the most destructive wildfire season in the province’s history, and record hot and dry conditions in the West also meant a year of distress for farmers and ranchers.

From a list of 100 significant weather events across Canada in 2017, Environment and Climate Change Canada’s experts have drawn up their choice of the Top 10 Weather Stories from across the country. To know more: http://ow.ly/AKbo30hn2st

From a list of significant weather events across Canada in , Environment and Climate Change Canada’s eerts have drawn up their choice of the Top Weather Stories from across the country. caption_original: The Supreme Court of Canada has ruled that there is an Aboriginal right to fish for food, social and ceremonial purposes. However, the buying, selling, trading, bartering or the offer to buy, sell, trade or barter Indigenous fishery resources harvested for food, social and ceremonial purposes is not permitted. Fishery Officers investigate any known or suspected incidents of persons engaging in illegal sale of fish and have authority under the Fisheries Act to fine or prosecute offenders.
caption_cleaned: The Supreme Court of Canada has ruled that there is an Aboriginal right to fish for food, social and ceremonial purposes. However, the buying, selling, trading, bartering or the offer to buy, sell, trade or barter Indigenous fishery resources harvested for food, social and ceremonial purposes is not permitted. Fishery Officers investigate any known or suspected incidents of persons engaging in illegal sale of fish and have authority under the Fisheries Act to fine or prosecute offenders.

caption_original:
We’re excited about our first confirmed 2017 sighting of a basking shark in BC waters! This big guy was spotted in Caamano Sound and measures approximately 17 feet!
Basking sharks are an endangered species under the Species At Risk Act, and have rarely been seen in North American Pacific waters over the last 15 years.
Thank you to Archie Dundas of the GitGa’at Guardians for the video of this basking shark.
caption_cleaned: We’re excited about our first confirmed sighting of a basking shark in BC waters! This big guy was spotted in Caamano Sound and measures approximately feet! Basking sharks are an endangered species under the Species At Risk Act, and have rarely been seen in North American Pacific waters over the last years. Thank you to Archie Dundas of the GitGa’at Guardians for the video of this basking shark.

caption_original: Look how far this Bluefin tuna travelled last winter! Our fishery officers and biologists worked together to recover a tag off Shippagan, New Brunswick, that had been attached to a Bluefin tuna for over a year. It showed the tuna was originally tagged on October 17, 2016 off of Port Mouton, Nova Scotia. The tuna stayed in Canadian waters until December and then travelled 3,000 km to the southwest of the Azores before making its way back to Nova Scotia in April. More info on how tagging helps us better understand the species: http://ow.ly/4FV830gHA0j

The tuna stayed in Canadian waters until December and then travelled ,000 km to the southwest of the Azores before making its way back to Nova Scotia in April. caption_original:
Over 5% of Canada’s oceans are now protected! We just reached and surpassed our national marine conservation target of protecting 5% of our marine and coastal areas by 2017 with the establishment of new marine refuges off the coast of British Columbia and Quebec. 🌊
Over the past year we have made huge strides in ocean protection. Creating three new Marine Protected Areas, marine refuges, and identifying a new Area of Interest. We’re on track to meet our goal of protecting 10% of Canadian oceans by 2020. http://ow.ly/7ILY30gc6Mi
caption_cleaned: Over % of Canada’s oceans are now protected! We just reached and surpassed our national marine conservation target of protecting % of our marine and coastal areas by with the establishment of new marine refuges off the coast of British Columbia and Quebec. Over the past year we have made huge strides in ocean protection. Creating three new Marine Protected Areas, marine refuges, and identifying a new Area of Interest. We’re on track to meet our goal of protecting % of Canadian oceans by .

caption_original:
Effective immediately, vessels travelling in the western Gulf of St. Lawrence are mandated to reduce their speed to a maximum of 10 knots. The Government of Canada implemented the temporary mandatory slow-down for vessels longer than 20 metres in an effort to minimize risks to right whales in the area.

 
Following the recent whale deaths in the Gulf of St. Lawrence, we are making every effort possible to prevent further incidents and continue to work on the recovery of the species. We are awaiting results from the necropsies, and we have closed snow crab fishing to prevent entanglements.  Other fixed gear fisheries such as rock and toad crab fisheries have either been restricted to fish in shallow water or have had a delayed opening. For more information on our actions to date: http://ow.ly/n5qc30el2Kw

Transport and Infrastructure in Canada
caption_cleaned: Effective immediately, vessels travelling in the western Gulf of St. Lawrence are mandated to reduce their speed to a maximum of knots. The Government of Canada implemented the temporary mandatory slow-down for vessels longer than metres in an effort to minimize risks to right whales in the area. Following the recent whale deaths in the Gulf of St. Lawrence, we are making every effort possible to prevent further incidents and continue to work on the recovery of the species. We are awaiting results from the necropsies, and we have closed snow crab fishing to prevent entanglements. Other fixed gear fisheries such as rock and toad crab fisheries have either been restricted to fish in shallow water or have had a delayed opening. For more information on our actions to date: Transport and Infrastructure in Canada

caption_original:
SCAM ALERT: Beware of scammers impersonating the Canada Revenue Agency (CRA). 

These scammers “spoof” phone numbers to make it look like the call is from the CRA claiming that you owe the government back taxes. These scammers threaten arrest if you don't make an immediate payment through untraceable money transfers and prepaid credit cards.  

Always be vigilant when disclosing personal and financial information. Here are some ways to tell if it's really the CRA: http://ow.ly/YExnK

caption_original:
The Department of Finance is getting ready for Budget 2016 and we want to hear from you. 

Leave your questions in the comment section below and Finance Minister Bill Morneau will answer some of them at one of two Facebook Live town hall events coming up on:
• January 11, from 3:00 p.m. to 4:00 p.m., Atlantic Standard Time, hosted by Dalhousie University; and
• January 15, from 2:00 p.m. to 2:50 p.m., Mountain Standard Time, hosted by the University of Calgary. 

Tune in here to watch these Facebook Live events on January 11th and 15th.

caption_original: EFFECTIVE TODAY! Canadians can subscribe to a basic TV package that costs no more than $25/month. As of March 1st, cable and satellite companies must also now offer PICK & PAY options: EITHER individual channels OR packages of up to 10 channels. Get more details here or contact your local cable provider: http://ow.ly/YT5FW
